plants.name: Prunus domestica
plants.description: Plum blossoms are among the earliest flowering trees in temperate climates, heralding the coming of spring. These flowers have a delicate and fragrant aroma and typically appear before the leaves do, creating striking displays of pink or white petals.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late winter to early spring (February to March)
plants.location: Temperate regions of East Asia, including Japan, China, and Korea
plants.funFact: Plum blossoms are a symbol of perseverance and hope in East Asian cultures, blooming despite the cold late-winter conditions.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: The Christmas rose is an evergreen perennial known for its ability to bloom in the depths of winter, often emerging through snow. Its large, cup-shaped flowers are usually white and sometimes tinged with pink or green.
plants.bloomingSeason: Winter to early spring (December to February)
plants.location: Mountainous regions of Central and Southern Europe
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas rose often blooms well into February, providing color when most plants are still dormant.

plants.name: Acacia dealbata
plants.description: The Silver Wattle is a fast-growing tree noted for its bright yellow, fluffy, ball-shaped flowers that bloom profusely. It is widely planted as an ornamental and valued for its early flowering in late winter.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late winter to early spring (January to March)
plants.location: Native to southeastern Australia; cultivated in Mediterranean climates worldwide
plants.funFact: In many Mediterranean countries, Acacia dealbata is celebrated in February festivals for its cheerful yellow blossoms signaling the end of winter.

plants.name: Narcissus spp.
plants.description: Daffodils are bulbous perennials well known for their trumpet-shaped flowers, which bloom in late winter to early spring. They often appear in gardens, naturalized woodland areas, and fields, signaling spring's arrival.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late winter to early spring (January to March)
plants.location: Native to Europe and North Africa; widely cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Daffodils contain toxic alkaloids that discourage herbivores, allowing them to bloom early without much disturbance.
